title.rendered: What are the most used scams and what should you avoid when buying NFTs?

content.rendered:
The NFT’s became popular in the field of technology and the video gameby presenting itself as a new option to be able to monetize through the virtual world.

However, buying these digital worksjust like a tangible product, has its pros and consso that users who want to access one of the tokens they risk facing a possible scam.

In this note we have compiled the most common cases of deception that use the criminalsso that you can be attentive and avoid a possible scam in your next purchase

Direct messages by Discord

The Discord platform has become one of the most used by young people, as well as by cybercriminals, who often scam users through messages in which, with just one click, their wallets valued at thousands of dollars are stolen. dollars in cryptocurrency. In addition to these messages, it is very common that they also violate access to app accounts.

Fake profiles on social networks

It may sound obvious, but given the exponential increase in accounts on different social networks, the community is more exposed to possible traps by criminals. It is enough to have a verification badge to be able to confuse an inexperienced Internet user, so it is sometimes necessary to hesitate when an unknown profile tries to communicate.

Fake web pages (phishing)

Like virtual stores, in recent years, so-called digital wallets have been established, which are nothing more than other fake websites that offer virtual products, such as NFTs, at a fairly affordable price. This scam method is more recurrent through links shared on social networks, as well as through emails.

Imitators of artists or creators

Finally, it is advisable to have direct communication with the official channels of the artists or designers of these digital pieces, because, if this is not the case, they may refer us to another user who is posing as the real one. The most recent case was that of Tyler Hobbs, the artist who created the Fidenza generative art collection, who denounced the SolBlocks platform for selling replicas of his work without his consent.
